statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: With the struggling Chicago Bulls in town, the New York Knicks were actually happy to play back-to-back games.
article.headline: Bulls now have lost 17 consecutive road games
article.linkText: Houston, Thomas help Knicks keep Bulls weary
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- With the struggling Chicago Bulls in town, the New York Knicks were actually happy to play back-to-back games. Allan Houston had 26 points and Kurt Thomas added 24 and 13 rebounds as the Knicks won 98-86 Tuesday night, handing the Bulls their 17th consecutive road defeat. Latrell Sprewell added 16 points for the Knicks, who hadn't won the second of back-to-back games in seven tries this season. Thomas had his third consecutive double-double and his 12th of the season as the Knicks didn't let the Bulls' young post players dominate like they did a night earlier in Chicago's 101-94 victory. ''I take pride in my defense, and when a guy outplays me as far as rebounding the ball, I take that to heart,'' Thomas said. ''This is one good thing about the schedule: When you have a home-and-home and a guy kicks your behind one night, you can come back the next night and kick his.'' Jalen Rose scored 23 points and Donyell Marshall 22 for the Bulls, who have not won on the road since beating Boston in their opener Oct. 30. Jamal Crawford added 15 points and helped Chicago cut the lead in the fourth quarter. Chicago got just 13 points and 18 rebounds from centers Tyson Chandler and Eddy Curry and forward Marcus Fizer. In Chicago's victory Monday, the trio had 35 points and 27 rebounds. Rookie Jay Williams went 0-for-7 from the field and had four turnovers, including three late in the third quarter. At the end of the period, the point guard slammed his fist on the scorer's table and put his head in his hands. He did not return to the game. ''It sure wasn't happening for me tonight,'' Williams said. ''I was horrible.'' Charlie Ward stole a pass from Crawford and hit a layup, and Houston hit a 3-pointer to push the Knicks' lead to 85-65 with 10:05 to go. Like the Bulls, though, who a night earlier had their 20-point fourth-quarter lead cut to five, the Knicks' advantage did not go unchallenged. Marshall had a dunk, Rose hit a 3-pointer and a jumper and Crawford made a 3 to cut the lead to 89-79 with 5:07 left and the Knicks' reserves floundering. Crawford cut the lead to seven by blocking Ward's 3-pointer and completing a 3-point play with 3:34 left. But Houston hit a 3 to push the lead back to 10 with 2:17 left. ''There was more of a sense of urgency in this for us,'' Houston admitted of finally winning the latter of back-to-back games. ''It was a mental challenge for us. It was a mental thing, not a physical thing. ''I was just glad to see us be able to do something, to do that and come through with a win.'' Thomas simply overmatched Chandler in the second half. Thomas dunked a miss, head-faked Chandler out of the way twice for jumpers and hit an open layup before Chandler sat down. Chicago's second-year center, who grabbed 19 rebounds in the Bulls' victory Monday, finished with four points and five rebounds in 15 minutes. Sprewell added to the lead, slashing for a flashy dunk and hitting a pair of jumpers that put the Knicks up 73-58 with 3:25 to go in the third. New York cut into Chicago's fourth-quarter lead to with 3-pointers Monday, and the Knicks stuck with the strategy Tuesday. Sprewell started the game by hitting a pair of 3-pointers, and the Knicks hit five of 11 shots from beyond the arc in the first half in building a 56-48 lead at the break. ''I feel horrible,'' Williams said. ''I don't know why. Losing 17 straight on the road will do that to you.'' Game notes
Bulls forward Corie Blount missed his second consecutive game with the flu. ... Knicks coach Don Chaney said his team usually lacks energy on the second day of back-to-back games, but wasn't taking that excuse Tuesday. ''We definitely shouldn't be tired after that performance'' on Monday, Chaney said. ... Reserve Marcus Fizer picked up two quick fouls in the first quarter, and during the ensuing timeout, he stormed out of the team discussion and sat on the baseline, but returned to action in the second quarter. ... The Knicks evened the overall seasons series at 85-85.
